qas.question: What video frequency does NTSC use?
What video frequency does PAL use?
How much slower do games run on PAL consoles than NTSC due to frequency differences?
What hardware modification could be made to the SNES to support game speed differences?

answers.text: a switch can be added to place the SNES PPU into a 60 Hz mode supported by most newer PAL televisions

qas.question: What video standard do PPU cartridges use?
What video standard to later games operate at?
How much slower are games on PPU consoles than PAL due to incompatibility?
What do SNES consoles face when facing a 20% speedup?
What does NTSC higher resolution result in?

context: PAL consoles face <b7_0>another incompatibility<b7_0/> when playing out-of-region cartridges: the NTSC video standard specifies video at <a0_0><b4_0>60 Hz<b4_0/><a0_0/> while PAL operates at <a1_0><b5_0>50 Hz<b5_0/><a1_0/>, resulting in approximately <a2_0><b6_0>16.7% slower<b6_0/><a2_0/> gameplay. Additionally, PAL's higher resolution results in <b8_0>letterboxing of the output image<b8_0/>. Some commercial PAL region releases exhibit this same problem and, therefore, can be played in NTSC systems without issue while others will face a 20% speedup if played in an NTSC console. To mostly correct this issue, <a3_0>a switch can be added to place the SNES PPU into a 60 Hz mode supported by most newer PAL televisions<a3_0/>. Later games will detect this setting and refuse to run, requiring the switch to be thrown only after the check completes.
